fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be transitive if it contains the relation (ap,bq)\colon R \times _{A} R\rightarrowtail A \times A, where p and q are given in the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {R \times _{A} R}, ne = R, sw = R, se = A, nw/style = pullback, north = q, west = p, south = b, east = a, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly, (a,b) is transitive if there is a morphism \tau \colon R \times _{A} R\to R such that a\tau = ap and b\tau = bq.
Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
